docs.lead_paragraph: The fatal blow fractured his skull, but that barely begins to account for the last, gruesome hours, in 1999, of a 21-month-old boy whose family had a history of child abuse and neglect. The medical examiner found 13 bruises on his head and neck, blunt trauma injuries on his torso, arms and legs, and even human bite marks. In 2002, a 12-year-old girl who had been sexually abused, had missed months of school, had seen her siblings neglected and had repeatedly threatened suicide, took a fatal overdose of a drug that her mother had failed to lock up.

headline.main: Behind Spotlight, Child Deaths Are Just One Gauge of System

docs.abstract: Public outrage at failure of New York City's child welfare system to prevent brutal death of 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown far exceeds what occurred in similar cases in past; this raises questions about just how much any single death reflects system's overall effectiveness; incidence of child fatalities in city has moved up and down from year to year, with some of lowest totals occurring in years when child welfare system was thought to be at its worst and some of highest totals coming well on into reform effort that would be hailed as national model; death reports make clear that, for all system's improvements, frequent mistakes are made by caseworkers; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Each year in the city's child welfare system some two dozen to three dozen children whose families had dealings with the authorities wound up dying.

byline.original: By RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA and ANDY NEWMAN
